currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

In my opinion, we should be worried.

 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should be worried.
The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should be worried.
The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places

The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed.

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving.

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking.

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., even in a social setting

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

In my opinion, we should be worried.
The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!

The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed.

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving.

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., even in a social setting

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should be worried.
The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes cva

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., even in a social setting

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should be worried.
The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes cvausing separatoion a

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., even in a social setting

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should be worried.
The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes causing separation and divorce

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometime sleading to c

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should be worried.
The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes causing separation and divorce

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometimes leading to choking

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, somwtim.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes causing separation and divorce

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometimes leading to choking

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, sometimes leading to slip-and-fall fatalities.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should be worried.
The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
.

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes causing separation and divorce

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometimes leading to choking

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, sometimes leading to slip-and-fall fatalities.

This is behavior reminiscent of that of an alcoholic or drug addict, not a well-adjusted person.

The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes causing separation and divorce

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometimes leading to choking

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, sometimes leading to slip-and-fall fatalities.

This is behavior reminiscent of that of an alcoholic or drug addict, not a well-adjusted person.

What can we do?

.

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, sometimes leading to slip-and-fall fatalities.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should be worried.
The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes causing separation and divorce

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometimes leading to choking

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, sometimes leading to slip-and-fall fatalities.

This is behavior reminiscent of that of an alcoholic or drug addict, not a well-adjusted person.

What can we do?

We can smash our phones, but how likely is that?

But we can be though

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should be worried.
The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes causing separation and divorce

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometimes leading to choking

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, sometimes leading to slip-and-fall fatalities.

This is behavior reminiscent of that of an alcoholic or drug addict, not a well-adjusted person.

What can we do?

We can smash our phones, but how likely is that?

But we can be thoughtful in our use of screen time, aiming for modera

 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes causing separation and divorce

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometimes leading to choking

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, sometimes leading to slip-and-fall fatalities.

This is behavior reminiscent of that of an alcoholic or drug addict, not a well-adjusted person.

What can we do?

We can smash our phones, but how likely is that?

But we can be thoughtful in our use of screen time, aiming for moderation rather than

 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes causing separation and divorce

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometimes leading to choking

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, sometimes leading to slip-and-fall fatalities.

This is behavior reminiscent of that of an alcoholic or drug addict, not a well-adjusted person.

What can we do?

We can smash our phones, but how likely is that?

But we can be thoughtful in our use of screen time, aiming for moderation rather than immersion.
We can be mindful of our screen use, and try to limit it to two hours a day.

We can avoid using our phones in public places.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes causing separation and divorce

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometimes leading to choking

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, sometimes leading to slip-and-fall fatalities.

This is behavior reminiscent of that of an alcoholic or drug addict, not a well-adjusted person.

What can we do?

We can smash our phones, but how likely is that?

But we can be thoughtful in our use of screen time, aiming for moderation rather than immersion.
We can be mindful of our screen use, and try to limit it to two hours a day.

We can avoid using our phones in public places.

We can avoid using our phones in bed.

We can avoid using our phones while driving.

We can avoid using our phones while walking.

We can avoid using our phones while eating.

We can avoid using our phones while in the bathroom.

We can avoid using our phones while in the shower.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometimes leading to choking

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, sometimes leading to slip-and-fall fatalities.

This is behavior reminiscent of that of an alcoholic or drug addict, not a well-adjusted person.

What can we do?

We can smash our phones, but how likely is that?

But we can be thoughtful in our use of screen time, aiming for moderation rather than immersion.
We can be mindful of our screen use, and try to limit it to two hours a day.

We can avoid using our phones in public places.

We can avoid using our phones in bed.

We can avoid using our phones while driving.

We can avoid using our phones while walking.

We can avoid using our phones while eating.

We can avoid using our phones while in the bathroom. 

We can avoid using our phones while in the shower. and the bath

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should be worried.
The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes causing separation and divorce

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometimes leading to choking

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, sometimes leading to slip-and-fall fatalities.

This is behavior reminiscent of that of an alcoholic or drug addict, not a well-adjusted person.

What can we do?

We can smash our phones, but how likely is that?

But we can be thoughtful in our use of screen time, aiming for moderation rather than immersion.
We can be mindful of our screen use, and try to limit it to two hours a day.

We can avoid using our phones in public places.

We can avoid using our phones in bed.

We can avoid using our phones while driving.

We can avoid using our phones while walking.

We can avoid using our phones while eating.

We can avoid using our phones while in the bathroom. or toilet

We can avoid using our phones while in the shower. and the bath

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should be worried.
The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes causing separation and divorce

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometimes leading to choking

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, sometimes leading to slip-and-fall fatalities.

This is behavior reminiscent of that of an alcoholic or drug addict, not a well-adjusted person.

What can we do?

We can smash our phones, but how likely is that?

But we can be thoughtful in our use of screen time, aiming for moderation rather than immersion.
We can be mindful of our screen use, and try to limit it to two hours a day.

We can avoid using our phones in public places.

We can avoid using our phones in bed.

We can avoid using our phones while driving.

We can avoid using our phones while walking.

We can avoid using our phones while eating.

We can avoid using our phones while in the bathroom. or toilet

We can avoid using our phones while in the shower. and the bath

---

In my opinion, we should be worried.
The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes causing separation and divorce

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometimes leading to choking

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, sometimes leading to slip-and-fall fatalities.

This is behavior reminiscent of that of an alcoholic or drug addict, not a well-adjusted person.

What can we do?

We can smash our phones, but how likely is that?

But we can be thoughtful in our use of screen time, aiming for moderation rather than immersion.
We can be mindful of our screen use, and try to limit it to two hours a day.

We can avoid using our phones in public places.

We can avoid using our phones in bed.

We can avoid using our phones while driving.

We can avoid using our phones while walking.

We can avoid using our phones while eating.

We can avoid using our phones while in the bathroom. or toilet

We can avoid using our phones while in the shower. and the bath

In my opinion, we should be worried.
The World Health Organization has issued a warning about the potential risks of excessive screen time during the pandemic.
 And they should know. Too much screen time has been reliably linked to depression, paranoia, anxiety, isolation, obesity and eyestrain. Compare this to a true human encounters, which have been reliably linked to happiness, friendship, love and hope. Quite a difference!
The WHO recommends that people limit their screen time to two hours a day., but true social media influencers put in two hours of social media before breakfast.
The WHO also recommends that people avoid using their phones in public places, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in public places
. 
The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones in bed, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones in bed., sometimes causing separation and divorce

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while driving, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while driving., sometimes leading to traffic fatalities

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while walking, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while walking., sometimes even walking into walls

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while eating, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while eating., sometimes leading to choking

The WHO recommends that people avoid using their phones while in the bathroom, but true social media influencers are constantly on their phones while in the
 bath and shower, sometimes leading to slip-and-fall fatalities.

This is behavior reminiscent of that of an alcoholic or drug addict, not a well-adjusted person.

What can we do?

We can smash our phones, but how likely is that?

But we can be thoughtful in our use of screen time, aiming for moderation rather than immersion.
We can be mindful of our screen use, and try to limit it to two hours a day.

We can avoid using our phones in public places.

We can avoid using our phones in bed.

We can avoid using our phones while driving.

We can avoid using our phones while walking.

We can avoid using our phones while eating.

We can avoid using our phones while in the bathroom. or toilet
